xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This study was financially supported by (1) the Gem and Jewelry Institute of Thailand (public organization) for field-work expenses and (2) the 90th Anniversary of Chulalongkorn University Fund (ratchadaphiseksomphot endowment fund) for laboratorial and other research expenses. The authors are gratefully appreciated the anonymous reviewers for valuable commends to improve the manuscript. Further profound acknowledgement goes to Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy for allowing us to access their prospecting area, providing transportation support and arranging Mr. Muia Boneface Mutunai to be our great assistant throughout the course of fieldwork. Additionally, the authors are thankful to Mr. Suvapak Imsamut from the Department of Mineral Resources of Thailand (DMR) for field-work assistance. The authors would like to extend deep appreciation to personnel from following institutes. (1) DMR: for providing XRF and FeO analyses and preparing thin and polished thin sections. (2) Department of Geoscience, National Taiwan University: for assistance on Ar-Ar dating and ICP-MS analyses; (3) Department of Earth Sciences, National Taiwan Normal University: for their kind hospitality; and (4) Department of Geology, Chulalonkorn University: for helping with EPMA procedure.

head.citation-title: Geochemical characteristics and new eruption ages of ruby-related basalts from southeast Kenya
head.abstracts: © 2014, China University of Geosciences and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.Two ruby-related basaltic fields were recently discovered in the southeast region of Kenya, exposed in the Nguu and Ngulai Hills vicinities. These fields host abundant deep-seated xenoliths, including corundum-bearing granulites. The basalts are alkaline affinity having compositions from foidrite to basanite. The Ngulai basalts have a wider range of SiO2 (38.2 wt.%–44.8 wt.%) covering those of the Nguu basalts (38.7 wt.%–42.3 wt.%). This overlapping behavior also holds for other major oxides and trace elements, e.g., Al2O3, Na2O, K2O, Cr, Ni, Rb and Ga. The overall OIB-like incompatible patterns with strong K depletion and slight spike of Ti enrichment signatures imply low degrees of partial melting of the upper mantle region source induced under a mantle plume-related process. The K-depletion signature indicates a residual K-bearing phase still retained in the source domain. Chondrite-normalized REE patterns exhibiting strong LREE enrichment without Eu anomalies suggest that plagioclase fractionation is insignificant. New 40Ar/39Ar ages indicate eruption events occurred during the Pleistocene times, which are around 2 Ma for the Ngulai basalts and 0.9 to 1.6 Ma for the Nguu basalts. Clinopyroxene-basalt thermobarometric calculations yield the equilibrium P-T ranges of ∼8-29 kbar and 1 200–1 450 °C.

coredata.dc:description: Two ruby-related basaltic fields were recently discovered in the southeast region of Kenya, exposed in the Nguu and Ngulai Hills vicinities. These fields host abundant deep-seated xenoliths, including corundum-bearing granulites. The basalts are alkaline affinity having compositions from foidrite to basanite. The Ngulai basalts have a wider range of SiO2 (38.2 wt.%–44.8 wt.%) covering those of the Nguu basalts (38.7 wt.%–42.3 wt.%). This overlapping behavior also holds for other major oxides and trace elements, e.g., Al2O3, Na2O, K2O, Cr, Ni, Rb and Ga. The overall OIB-like incompatible patterns with strong K depletion and slight spike of Ti enrichment signatures imply low degrees of partial melting of the upper mantle region source induced under a mantle plume-related process. The K-depletion signature indicates a residual K-bearing phase still retained in the source domain. Chondrite-normalized REE patterns exhibiting strong LREE enrichment without Eu anomalies suggest that plagioclase fractionation is insignificant. New 40Ar/39Ar ages indicate eruption events occurred during the Pleistocene times, which are around 2 Ma for the Ngulai basalts and 0.9 to 1.6 Ma for the Nguu basalts. Clinopyroxene-basalt thermobarometric calculations yield the equilibrium P-T ranges of ∼8-29 kbar and 1 200–1 450 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Geochemical characteristics and new eruption ages of ruby-related basalts from southeast Kenya
